Point 2: The core problem for Best Buy isn't Amazon, it's the deterioration of Best Buy's own service. The issues that Mr. Streitfeld (who I've raked over the coals before) found in his local Best Buy are the kinds of problems that customers have complained about for years, ever since the company jettisoned its most experienced (and expensive) salespeople in order to save money. For many customers, Best Buy's last minute Christmas order cancellations will be the last straw.

Most companies that fail do so because of self-inflicted wounds, not because of things that either competitors or the economy do to them. I agree with other commenters that Best Buy is headed down the same path as Circuit City, and toward the same outcome, unless it makes some big changes quickly.

'...Family-friendly work places are good for everybody, including non-parents...'

The problem is that this is not true. The US has a competitive business culture and anyone who is not around because of 'child care issues' means that someone else winds up doing their work.

Resentment builds when the same people are asked to stay late because their co-workers have children. And there is always a reason the parent cannot stay late or has to leave early. That is not fair or right. For certain, parents who work shorter hours should not expect the same rewards as the workers who focus all their attention on their jobs.

Children require sacrifices and one of those may be living cheaper, so one parent can stay at home, even moving someplace cheaper in order to do this.

What it shouldn't require is your co-workers sacrificing their own time on your behalf. I see no reason that my time with my family is more important than my childless co-worker's time out drinking with his buddies.

And, yes, I am a working mother, who sees first hand how parents expect special treatment when it comes to their time off.

1. Gary Johnson is about to announce a third-party candidacy in New Mexico as the candidate of the state's Libertarian Party. NM rules make it a virtual certainty that he will get on the ballot. Given that NM Repubs lean both conservative and libertarian, it would not surprise me if he got more votes than Romney. One thing is certain -- Obama will get NM's five electoral votes.

If Johnson is running in any other state, he has not said so thus far. It would not surprise me if he ran in Arizona as well (again, lots of libertarians), but I am not familiar with the ballot rules in that state.

2. What would cause Paul to "reconsider his views" if elected is the reality that we elect a chief executive, not a king. Even a Republican Congress would fight Paul tooth-and-nail on most of his signature issues (not to mention that the Democrats would use the filibuster to block his wilder schemes) and of course the judiciary gets to weigh in as well. Here in New Mexico our governor -- a conservative Republican -- has had four major policy setbacks at the hands of the courts, which ruled that she stretched the rules (e.g., tried to use the line item veto to reduce an appropriation rather than veto it outright).

If Paul could hold office for most of a generation, and FDR did, perhaps he could sculpt Congress and the courts to his liking. But two terms ain't enough.

In France it is against the law to discount books by more than 5%.. The purpose of this law - it has been successful - is to protect the single-owner neighborhood bookshop, to foster a diverse universe of book publishers, especially those who tend to publish more intellectual, literary, and experimental works and whose viability as publishers does not depend on blockbuster sales, The result is a more diverse world of more authors and readers.

Amazon has virtually destroyed the independent bookseller in America. The result is the big box chain store, same store, same books, in each city, each staffed by "associates." In each of the 4 stores in my Parisian neighborhood, the owners are behind the counter and we talk about books. Bookstores employ book lovers.

The French relationship to books and thus to the mind, is one of the great differences that I experience between the two cultures. In the American model, books are a commodity. It does not matter what’s in the books or how they are distributed; what matters is how many books you sell. The French have a culture to protect; the Americans think not of culture but profit. The American model needs not a thinker or a reader, but a consumer – and in this model it is better to buy more, even if of lower quality, because two illustrated cookbooks in the shopping cart is better than one slender volume of poetry or philosophy. The Amazon bomb has gone off. What’s left is a wasteland. A dumbing down of a people.

"The old classic has a point - it's good to believe in something despite common sense"

Why? In what world is that "good"? Is it good to believe that your house will clean itself? Is it good to believe that despite more extreme weather, we don't need to change our behavior to stave off disaster? Is it good to believe that clapping your hands makes you rich?

Nonsense. It's good to pay attention to facts and believe what they show you.

We love the myth and magic of Santa, and I as an adult still believe in that.

I do admit what we've struggled with this year in terms of Santa is the manipulation of children - telling kids that he only comes if they're "good" (and honestly it's not effective manipulation because he always comes. In families where they can't afford gifts, it's because they're broke. Not because the kids are bad.) We avoided telling our son that he had to be "good" for Santa, but plenty of well meaning old men on the subway told my son that he had to be good or Santa wasn't coming. My son is three. We love him unconditionally. I want him to think that Santa does too.

Last night we watched Miracle on 34th Street. The old classic has a point - it's good to believe in something despite common sense. And Santa is an idea that needs a lot of help from a lot of parents.

The siren song was loud and compelling in 2005, that anyone not jumping into housing in a big, and leveraged way, was some kind of fool. When I re-fi'ed in 2006 for remodelling and to pull in the term, two neighbors implored me to cash out even more to leverage investments as I had plenty equity. I looked at them funny, they told me I was naive and not possessed of a business mind.

Aren't things so different now! Those neighbors? They're the ardent Tea Partiers on our block. But if they were running Fannie and Freddie, they would have jumped in too!

How do they now regard their earlier stance regarding real estate and leveraging, you ask? Well, to them, it's all about how "they" ruined the game. "They" - you know, the ones who were benefited by the Community Reinvestment Act of the '70s. Gives one an insight as to how and why that particular part of the Big Lie took hold, doesn't it.
